content.question: A rotating object has an angular position represented by <math alttext="theta equals, A plus B t, plus C t squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Î¸</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , where <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are constants. A student wants to represent a different rotating object that has twice the angular speed at every moment. To write the new function, the student could

choices.label: double both <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

double both <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

double both <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: double both <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
